email.subject: RE: Application details
email.body_preview:
Leo,
                Sorry for the late response (traveling).

The short answer is add yet another VPX card into the mix aka APNT card (see below).  The problem is that lead time and delivery will be extended as we add that profile into the backplane (
email.body_text:
Leo,
Sorry for the late response (traveling).

The short answer is add yet another VPX card into the mix aka APNT card (see below).  The problem is that lead time and delivery will be extended as we add that profile into the backplane (requiring NRE and development time).  Also, these systems are meant add GPS into the system and not just timing distribution.  Also,  the clock drivers are not aligned as well as they could be (amplitude vs phase alignment).   So as a clock distribution circuit they may not be optimal for things like beamforming or direction finding.

The long answer is to develop your own pps to 10MHz sync/distribution system with external source and we wire this into one of the inputs from the I/O panel.   It’s the easiest but finding the one that meets your specifications is where you’d have to guide us.  We add some NRE for tha integration but lead time is dependent on finding that distribution module.
Another way is to use something from Epiq designed specifically for the VPX card.
https://epiqsolutions.com/products/crs/ndr505  - it looks like they make something for Los but not sure about 1pps to 10MHz alignment – need to check with them.

APNT cards.
https://brandywinecomm.com/product/vpx-timing-card/
https://defense-solutions.curtisswright.com/media-center/news/sosa-aligned-pnt-module

Regards,
William J. Pilaud
Chief Solutions Architect
LCR Embedded Systems, Inc.
Cell: (978) 231-3170
Web: www.lcrembeddedsystems.com<http://www.lcrembeddedsystems.com/>
Customer Driven.  Experienced Team. Proven 100Gig Rugged Products

AR01-310A-005-1

email.subject: RE: Quote Approval Work Flow
email.body_preview:
Abby;

I did some research into the Lead to Opportunity process. Apparently, I have the setting correct, and it is working correctly. Unfortunately, you have to manually select the “Trach Can” after selecting “Qualify” to keep the system from creating t
email.body_text:
Abby;

I did some research into the Lead to Opportunity process. Apparently, I have the setting correct, and it is working correctly. Unfortunately, you have to manually select the “Trach Can” after selecting “Qualify” to keep the system from creating the Opportunity.

Please pass this on to your team to see if options 1 or 2 are easy to implement.

Shan

In Dynamics 365 Sales Hub, when you qualify a Lead:

*   ✔ Create Account = Yes
*   ✔ Create Contact = Yes
*   ✖ Create Opportunity = No
The system will still default to creating an Opportunity unless you manually remove it using the trash can icon in the qualification dialog.
The “No” you’re seeing is not a hard setting — it’s simply showing the current selection state. If the Opportunity line remains visible and you do not remove it, it will be created.
Why This Happens
In standard configuration:

*   The Qualify Lead dialog automatically prepares:
*   Account (if none exists)
*   Contact (if none exists)
*   Opportunity (always prepared by default)
The Opportunity is considered part of the qualification process unless explicitly removed.
The checkbox/Yes-No display does not suppress creation by itself.
You must click the 🗑 trash icon to prevent the Opportunity from being created.
Important Clarification
There are two different things that often get confused:

1.  System behavior during qualification (default OOB behavior)
2.  Admin-level configuration to disable automatic opportunity creation
Even if you’ve disabled automatic opportunity creation in settings, the Qualify dialog can still present it unless additional customization has been done.
If You Want It to Truly NOT Create Opportunities Automatically
You have three options:
Option 1 – Train Users to Remove It
Simple but manual:

*   Select Lead
*   Click Qualify
*   Click trash can next to Opportunity
*   Confirm

Option 2 – JavaScript Customization (Cleaner UX)
Customize the command bar so:

*   Opportunity is removed by default
*   Or hide the Opportunity row completely
This requires Power Apps customization.
Option 3 – Replace Qualify Process with Custom Flow (Best Long-Term)
Create a custom button that:

*   Sets lead status to Qualified
*   Creates Account
*   Creates Contact
*   Does NOT create Opportunity
This gives you full control.

All,

Wanted to share current status.

Customer (Ronnen) is not willing to accept unit 2 until the acoustic noise issue gets resolved.  I shared that the quote for proposed fan solution was in the final stages of review, but we wouldn’t likely be able to implement the upgrade and ship by end of next week.   I reported we were committed to working with him to address this, but he wasn’t open to taking a 2nd unit (even it shipped in place and left at LCR).   He reported they were scheduled to start doing integration testing on the 20th and the unit is currently “not workable”, but will use it until unit 2 arrives.    We need to get the quote out first of next week and work to get unit 2 upgraded as quickly as possible.

Regards,

LCR-Security Warning: This email originated from outside of LCR organization. Please proceed with caution when clicking links or opening attachments.

Dear,

LCR EMBEDDED SYSTEMS, LLC

Please confirm receipt of this Request for Proposal (RFP) as soon as possible.

We are pleased to invite you to submit a Firm Fixed Price quote for (LCR3KM_2):

Line Item 1:  ANGREBIRD JR. Mod Kit (QTY 1)

  *   (Qty 1) Standalone PCB Backplane with full P2 Cutout to accommodate V67.3C connector (Prefer slot#5; however, defer decision by LCR that provides least schedule/cost increase)
  *   (Qty 4) Fiber cable to connect front panel fiber connector to front panel of FPGA – 24-fiber MT to 24-fiber MPO, as loose parts

Line Item 2: DH Chassis Mod Kit (QTY 2)

  *   (Qty 2) Fiber cable to connect between the chassis front panel and the top of the Amphenol Switch LEAP Connector – 24F MT to 24M MT, as loose parts
  *   (Qty 1) Ethernet media converter kit, to include mounting hardware and all required interface cables (RJ45 to Meritec)
  *   (Qty 2) Odd Fat Pipe Meritec Cable to route between GPP and GPU slot
  *   (Qty 2) Odd Fat Pipe Meritec Cable to route between GPP and FPGA slot
  *   (Qty 2) Even Thin Pipe Meritec Cable to route MP01 port of GPP (Concurrent TR-MDA) to front panel

The attached documents outline the requirements for an ADP program with Lockheed Martin Aeronautics, and your proposal will play a crucial role in our evaluation process for awarding a Firm Fixed Price subcontract.

Please review the attached documents, including the Request for Proposal and other relevant materials. We require your acceptance of the attached LM Aero terms and conditions. If you disagree with any provisions, please use Microsoft Word's track changes feature to propose revisions and return the revised document as part of your proposal submission. Please acknowledge receipt of these documents and include any revised terms and conditions with your proposal response.

To ensure timely receipt, please confirm receipt of this RFP within 48 hours. This will enable us to verify that you have received the necessary documents.

The proposal is due on [3/5/2026]. Please note that the quote must remain in effect for a period of 60 days, and an authorized representative must sign the response to bind your company to a subcontract of the proposed magnitude. The quote must include your company's legal name, state of incorporation, and complete address.

The attached documents include:

  *   10662: Request for Proposal, which outlines our terms and conditions, as well as the documents included in the RFP package
  *   10665: Solicitation Instructions, which details specific requirements that must be included in your proposal

When pricing your proposal, please consider the current level of effort expected and be aware that a proposal or contract modification may be necessary upon completion of engineering designs, which may require part modifications and updated pricing. Any future price increases must be justified with supporting documentation.

If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to contact us. We look forward to receiving your proposal.


Thank you,

Kimberly Meza
ADP Subcontract Management
Lockheed Martin Aeronautics Company

subject: LCRs Updated Schedule Improvements and Assumptions

email.subject: LCRs Updated Schedule Improvements and Assumptions
email.body_preview:
Pete,

From the Wed update there was an improvement in the schedule for the 25-piece order and I discussed the key points for the effort that our Management and Operations Teams did to improve the timeline. Of note, many of the improvements are based up
email.body_text:
Pete,

From the Wed update there was an improvement in the schedule for the 25-piece order and I discussed the key points for the effort that our Management and Operations Teams did to improve the timeline. Of note, many of the improvements are based upon assumptions as we move from a singular prototype unit into full production in under two months. I wanted to amplify some of those notes on how LCR plans to achieve this improved schedule. LCR analyzed the build process and is working towards the key areas listed below.

*   Stabilize Current Build Process
*   Material Availability: Ensure all required material is available to support planned start dates
*   Quality Execution: With material stabilized consistent workflow and quality will improve to reduce major disruptions
*   Optimized Efficiency: Build performance will improve with repletion and allow additional analysis on time saving measures
*   Sub-Assembly Stability: 25-unit order sub-level scope stabilized following outsourcing optimization
*   Schedule Compression Drivers
*   Refined hours-per-unit estimates driving reduced overall duration
*   Early PC Board-level validation improving downstream testing and workflow
*   Controlled release of subassemblies enabling smoother floor execution

Thank you,

Peter Lueck
Program Manager

email.subject: Early Funding Award
email.body_preview:
Brad;

I spoke with David F. last night, and he informed me that Textron had approved funding for the development assets and NRE to kick off the program with LCR. This is fantastic news for our team, and we appreciate the extensive efforts made by Textr
email.body_text:
Brad;

I spoke with David F. last night, and he informed me that Textron had approved funding for the development assets and NRE to kick off the program with LCR. This is fantastic news for our team, and we appreciate the extensive efforts made by Textron to get us to this point.

I know that over the last 10 days, there has been significant back and forth between LCR and Textron to review/confirm the best payload package to meet the requirements of the program. Although this added some last-minute confusion, I believe the outcome will yield a smoother execution and reduced risk to the program. The fact that we have our engineering teams clarifying requirements and defining scope early will pay dividends on the backend!

The team at LCR is excited to get started, and we look forward to working together.

Regards,
Shan Morgan
President

email.subject: RE: L3H CLC lob and status update
email.body_preview:
Team,

Some updates.


  *   First – Update on metal from EMC.
  *   Second - Update on EE design changes


  *   First metal from EMC.
     *   The first TAN weldment with the fixed holes and paint mask issue and the remake of PS mounting brack
email.body_text:
Team,

Some updates.

*   First – Update on metal from EMC.
*   Second - Update on EE design changes

*   First metal from EMC.
*   The first TAN weldment with the fixed holes and paint mask issue and the remake of PS mounting brackets were targeted to ship today.   Due to 4 or 5 EMC employees out with FLU each day this week, they got behind.   The updated projected shipment schedule is shown below.

*   We also need to get a quote from EMC through normal channels (not NPI) to make the switch from TAN to GRAY.   We’ll need to return the items listed below.  See RETURN QTY for # to be quoted and returned.   Need to start the return process.
*   @Benjamin Jacob<mailto:bjacob@lcrembedded.com> @Noel Kenny<mailto:nkenny@lcrembedded.com> with Sonya out can you support this request?
*   @Jerry Schock<mailto:JSchock@lcrembedded.com> @Teresa Movafegh<mailto:TMovafegh@lcrembedded.com> we’ll need the drawings updated to reflect the Gray Callout.
*   @Noel Kenny<mailto:nkenny@lcrembedded.com> what is the status of the NCM for the chassis weldment 1249-99-001 that got written up?   Need to work on getting this returned.

*   Update on EE design changes
*   New cable adapters are being designed to address a design pinout issue.  See attached PPT put together by David J for details.  One plugs into the backplane and the other plugs into the chassis manager adapter board.
*   For unit 1 and possibly unit 2 both adapters will be installed and shipped on a Waiver.
*   For unit 2 thru 7 the backplane adapter will be used but not the chassis manager adapter.
*   Due to the attachment to the chassis manager adapter not being adequate for production shipment as outline in the attachment, a chassis manager PCB spin is in progress.
*   David J plans to release the cable adapter design files tomorrow.
*   Charles is working on an update to the chassis manager adapter board and hopes to have it out by the of next week.
*   @Benjamin Jacob<mailto:bjacob@lcrembedded.com> @Daniel Durham<mailto:DDurham@lcrembedded.com> these changes will drive need for material procurement.

Regards,
Donald Germany
Program Manager

email.subject: RE: New Quote task assigned for: Q260533 CRM:0476633
email.body_preview:
Darwin,

The team reviewed the engineering hours and feel these hours have been accurately estimated for the SNC 10+2 opportunity.

One factor that is driving the electrical hours is the routing complexity associated to the 6 slots of SLT3-PAY-1F1U1S1
email.body_text:
Darwin,

The team reviewed the engineering hours and feel these hours have been accurately estimated for the SNC 10+2 opportunity.

One factor that is driving the electrical hours is the routing complexity associated to the 6 slots of SLT3-PAY-1F1U1S1S1U1U2F1H-14.6.11.   It was also assumed these signals will be routed with high-speed design rules in mind.

The other factor that is driving the electrical hours is the loose requirements on I/O.  The estimated hours assume a high count of ethernet and discrete signals that would need to be off-boarded.

If and/or when the customer further defines their architecture and system needs, we can re-review these estimated hours.

Thanks,
Rick

email.body_preview:
RJ,

Noel is in daily conversations and we almost have the PO set. There was one open question on the x-rays that I wanted to run past your team before responding to NSI.

On the x-rays they are making sure they can meet the size requirement and have
email.body_text:
RJ,

Noel is in daily conversations and we almost have the PO set. There was one open question on the x-rays that I wanted to run past your team before responding to NSI.

On the x-rays they are making sure they can meet the size requirement and have asked for this information: “only open is the size of voids in solder ..and the size and width of the solder . in lieu of a standard”. The reason is that the accuracy that NSI has is their x-rays 10 -15 microns . If you want deeper/ granular data it would need a Nano Tube ..  That is beyond NSI.

I am just making sure we are in alignment to reduce errors and concerns.

Peter

Steve;

Attached is a table of the VME64X and CPCI backplanes we have sold in the past. I would like to get a table added to the website, noting that we have the 5, 7, 12 and 21 slots versions of the VME64X backplanes “readily available”. We want to pus
email.body_text:
Steve;

Attached is a table of the VME64X and CPCI backplanes we have sold in the past. I would like to get a table added to the website, noting that we have the 5, 7, 12 and 21 slots versions of the VME64X backplanes “readily available”. We want to push that they are IEEE 1101.10 and VITA compliant and ideal for supporting legacy programs. Note that they have multiple power connection options for to support Power Bugs, Power Studs or Bus Bars.

Richard has included the drawings for these in the associated tabs. Please add these as reference documents to the Web (5, 7, 12, & 21). Also not that other sizes 2-21 are available for special order.

If you have questions, let me know.

Shan
